An investment firm that buys and sells stocks is developing a formula that uses data from the stock market to signal when certain stocks should be bought or sold. The firm plans to investigate the performance of two different formulas (J and K) across its large portfolio of stocks. A random sample of <math alttext="38" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>38</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> stocks was selected from those in the firm’s portfolio. For one year, both formulas examined the data for each stock and issued signals to either buy the stock when it predicted a price increase or sell the stock when it predicted a price decrease. The difference in formula performance, measured by the difference in the proportion of price increases and decreases correctly predicted, was recorded for each stock at the end of the one year. The histogram shows the distribution of the differences in formula performance (J minus K) for the <math alttext="38" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>38</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> stocks. (a) Describe the distribution of the differences in formula performance for the <math alttext="38" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>38</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> stocks.

The investment firm will use a hypothesis test, at <math alttext="alpha equals 0.02" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.02</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that Formula J has a lower formula performance than Formula K. Let <math alttext="mu sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean difference in formula performance (J minus K) for all stocks in the firm’s portfolio that could be examined by the two formulas. The hypotheses are: <math alttext="H sub 0, colon, mu sub difference equals 0. H sub a, colon, mu sub difference is less than 0." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (b) Identify a feature of the distribution of the sample differences in formula performance that might raise concerns about whether the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal, and explain why it is reasonable to conclude that the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal in this case.

Assuming all conditions for inference were met, the hypothesis test was conducted and resulted in a test statistic of <math alttext="t is approximately equal to negative 4.936" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≈</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>4.936</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(c) Based on the result of the hypothesis test, what conclusion can be made about the two formulas? Justify your answer.

A stock trader at the investment firm believes that formula performance is related to average daily stock volume (number of shares of each stock that are traded per day). The scatterplots show, by formula, the relationship between average daily stock volume and formula performance for the <math alttext="38" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>38</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> stocks. (d) Describe and compare the association between average daily stock volume and formula performance for the two formulas.

(e) Suppose a stock is randomly selected from those in the study. For which formula (J or K) is there a smaller probability of selecting a stock that has a formula performance of at least <math alttext="0.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> given an average daily stock volume of at least <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> million shares? Interpret what this means in the context of the study.

(f) Provide a recommendation to the investment firm that describes how stocks should be assigned to Formula J or Formula K based on average daily stock volume if the goal is to assign the formula with the greater formula performance. Justify your answer based on the two scatterplots.
